Constitution for the Campus Kitchen Project at Georgia Tech

Created 12/18/2015
Revised 2/21/2018

Article I – Name
This organization will be known as The Campus Kitchen Project at Georgia Tech, a chapter of the national Campus Kitchens Project organization, hereafter referred to as CKP.

Article II – Purpose
The purpose of CKP is to:
  1. Reduce food waste by repurposing and packaging meals from on-campus dining facilities to feed food-insecure members of Georgia Tech and the Atlanta community;
  2. Strengthen bodies by using existing resources to meet hunger and nutritional needs in our community
  3. Provide students opportunities to increase awareness of physical needs of socioeconomically disadvantaged members of our community;
  4. Build communities by fostering a new generation of community-minded adults through resourceful and mutually beneficial partnerships among students, social service agencies, businesses and schools.

Article III - Membership
  1. Members of CKP will be Georgia Tech students who meet eligibility requirements for participation in extracurricular activities as stated in the GT Catalog and SGA policies. Only Georgia Tech students can vote or hold office.

  2. Officers (including executive officers) will be the only members of the organization. There is no maximum number of members. Executive officers consist of the President, VP of Growth, VP of Volunteering, VP of Finance, VP of Records, and the Klemis Liaison.

  3. Executive officers will be required to attend 75% of the organization meetings each semester, and may be excused if their absence is pre-approved by the President. Other officers will be required to attend monthly general officer meetings.

  4. A volunteer is any person that has attended at least one shift but is not a voting member. A volunteer is an associate member. Volunteers must abide by the Georgia Tech rules and GT Campus Kitchen confidentiality and regulations. Volunteers can can be anyone affiliated with Georgia Tech.

Section I- Membership Process

  1. Membership will take effect when officers are selected by the Executive Board based on applications and the needs of the organization.

2. Associate membership will take effect when a person signs up for a shift on Orgsync and attends a shift.

Article IV – Officers

Section 1. According to the GT Catalog, students can only run for, and hold office if they are in good standing with the Institute (academically and non-academically).

Section 2. An Executive Board comprised of Officers will govern the activities of the organization, and the specific duties of the Officers will be as follows:

1. President: The President will be the executive officer of the Executive Board and will have general supervision of the affairs of CKP and will preside at meetings. The President will represent the organization at conferences, conventions and faculty or alumni meetings, as well as the national CKP. The President will also be responsible for ensuring that the organization is following all guidelines set by the national organization.

2. Vice-President of Volunteering: The Vice-President of Volunteering will be the junior executive officer and will act on the behalf of the President in the event of his/her absence. He or she will also be responsible for coordinating volunteer shifts and expanding the volunteer base. He or she will be responsible for maintaining food safety standards in alignment with ServSafe and other federal, state, and local food safety guidelines.

3. Vice-President of Growth Strategy: The Vice-President of Growth Strategy will be responsible for expanding the organization’s ability to combat hunger and food waste in the Georgia Tech community and Atlanta area.

4. Vice-President of Records: The Vice-President of Records will record the proceedings of each meeting, distribute the minutes to the members, and maintain the membership roster. He or she will also be responsible for managing the social media and web presence of the organization, as well as maintaining CKP’s standard operating procedures.

5. Vice-President of Finance and Special Projects: The Vice-President of Finance will maintain records of all revenue and expenditures and ensure that generally accepted accounting practices and monetary controls are in place. The Vice-President of Finance will collect dues. They will also be responsible for all special projects for CKP, including supporting Klemis Kitchen management in partnership with institute staff.

6. Klemis Liaison: The Klemis Liaison is in charge of maintaining the upkeep of Klemis Kitchen. They will check the Klemis space weekly, and notify the President of any issues. Issues consist of the space needing cleaning, inadequate food supply, and any other problems with the physical space. They are in charge of scheduling shifts for cleaning Klemis and of initiatives to improve the space.

Article V– Officer Elections

1. The elections for officers for the forthcoming year will take place at the end of Fall semester no later than four weeks before finals.
2. Election timeline and nomination processes must be announced to members at least two weeks prior to the elections meeting.
3. Any existing member or volunteer that has attended at least 3 shifts may campaign or be nominated for any position on the Executive Board. The candidate names will be distributed to organization members at least 24 hours prior to the election meeting.
4. Newly elected officers shall assume their respective duties within fourteen(14) days following their election at a time designated by the outgoing President.
5. The candidate for each office receiving a majority vote of members at the elections meeting will be considered the victor. If no candidate receives a majority vote, then there will be a runoff between the two candidates with the most votes. The candidate who receives the most votes will be the victor. If there is a tie, the highest ranking outgoing officer not involved in the run-off will make the final decision. No member can be elected to more than one position on the Executive Board at one time.
6. If a position remains unfilled after the elections process the President will appoint a member to the position or reassign duties to another officer.

Article VI- Officer Removal
    1. If an officer fails to maintain Institute requirements as stated in the GT Catalog and Article 4 Section 1, he or she shall resign immediately.

    2. If it is believed that an officer is not fulfilling his or her constitutional duties, then a petition requesting his or her removal must be signed by at least half of the voting membership or Executive Board and presented at a general meeting or Executive Board meeting depending on the origin of the petition. Then, upon verification of the validity of the petition, by the Advisor, and, at least two weeks but no more than four weeks from the date of submission, another meeting shall be held at which the grievance will be presented, with both sides having the opportunity to present a case.

    3. The Advisor, if appropriate, shall preside over the removal hearing. After all arguments have been heard, a secret-ballot vote shall be held. If at least two-thirds of the voting members present vote for removal, the officer shall be removed immediately.

    4. If the President is removed or resigns, the Vice-President of Volunteering will take his/her place in the interim until the next election cycle. All other officers will be nominated by the membership and voted on in accordance with Article V at the next meeting. In this case, the victor will take office immediately following election and will fulfill the term of the officer that he or she is replacing.

Article VII- Committees
    1. Committees may be created as necessary by the President for specific events and projects not to last longer than the current officer term.
    2. Each committee will have a chair, as appointed by the executive board.
    3. Any member or officer may be selected as a committee chair.
    4. Any number of members may be on a committee.

Article VIII – Advisor
    1. A full-time salaried GT faculty or staff member will serve as Advisor to the organization.

    2. Nominations for Advisor will take place within the Executive Board. An Advisor will be chosen within two weeks of a vacancy. The Executive Board will choose the Advisor by a majority vote and invite him/her to serve as Advisor for the next academic year.

    3. During officer elections, the organization will vote on whether to continue the Advisor appointment or not. The vote must be a majority of those voting in order to retain the Advisor for the next academic year.

    4. The duties of Advisor include: meeting with organization officers, reviewing the yearly budget, signing all required paperwork and advising on issues of risk management, organization leadership, and Georgia Tech policy.

    5. The Advisor can be removed for not carrying out the duties and expectations as defined in this document. Any member can bring concerns to the Executive Board. The Executive Board will meet with the Advisor to discuss the concerns. After this meeting, the Executive Board will vote on whether to remove the Advisor. If there is a majority vote, then the Advisor will be removed

    6. If an Advisor steps down, is removed, or is not re-appointed, the Executive Board will follow the process stated in Article VIII, B.

Article IX - Dues
    1. Dues will be determined at the beginning of the year by a majority vote of the Executive Board but will not be less than the required amount designated by the Student Government Association Joint Finance Committee Policy. Dues are to be paid by the third week of the semester or by the second week of membership.

Article X – Parliamentary Procedure
    1. Robert’s Rules of Order will be used in instances not covered in this constitution.

Article XI – Constitutional Amendments
    1. Amendments to the constitution shall be submitted by members of this organization to the Executive Board in writing for consideration.

    2. Written notification of the proposed amendment to all voting members must be made by mail or email, at least two weeks in advance of any vote on changes in the constitution.

    3. A two-thirds vote of members present will be required for adoption.

    4. Amendments are subject to the approval of the Student Government Association and the Student Activities Committee.
